text: 1.​ Match Baud Rates on Both Ends​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Always ensure that both transmitting and receiving devices operate at the
label: SUBSECTION

text: same baud rate (e.g., 9600, 115200 bps) to avoid data corruption.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Configure the microcontroller’s TX and RX pins in alternate function mode
label: SUBSECTION

text: Don’t forget to enable the UART or USART peripheral clock in your
label: SUBSECTION

text: microcontroller's RCC or clock control module.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Choose correct frame parameters like word length (usually 8 or 9 bits),
label: SUBSECTION

text: number of stop bits (1 or 2), and parity (none, even, odd) to match the

text: 5.​ Use Pull-up Resistors on RX Line (if needed)​
label: SUBSECTION

text: On some boards, the RX line may float and cause false starts. Use a pull-up
label: SUBSECTION

text: For efficiency, use UART receive/transmit interrupts instead of polling. This
label: SUBSECTION

text: avoids CPU blocking during data transmission.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: 7.​ Use DMA for Large Data Transfers​
label: SUBSECTION

text: In high-speed applications, Direct Memory Access (DMA) can offload CPU
label: SUBSECTION

text: 8.​ Design Circular Buffers for RX and TX​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Implement ring buffers for storing incoming and outgoing data streams. This
label: SUBSECTION

text: prevents data loss and makes buffering more robust.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Some UART peripherals need a few clock cycles or milliseconds of delay
label: SUBSECTION

text: after reset or power-up before being configured.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: UART timing depends on system clock. Ensure the main clock is accurate
label: SUBSECTION

text: enough for the selected baud rate.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: cause system hangs and missed UART events.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Monitor and clear error flags such as framing error, overrun error, and noise
label: SUBSECTION

text: Always check that the transmit buffer is empty before writing new data,
label: SUBSECTION

text: especially when sending manually without interrupts.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: 14.​Include Start and Stop Bits in Framing​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Remember that UART automatically adds start and stop bits. You don’t need
label: SUBSECTION

text: to add them manually in software.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: For reliable high-speed communication, enable RTS/CTS hardware flow
label: SUBSECTION

text: control if supported by both devices.​
label: SUBSECTION

text: Use shielded cables and proper grounding if UART lines run over long
label: SUBSECTION

text: When using interrupts on ARM-based MCUs, make sure to enable the
label: SUBSECTION

text: UART IRQ in the Nested Vectored Interrupt Controller (NVIC).​

text: If UART devices operate at different voltage levels (e.g., 5V and 3.3V), use a
label: SUBSECTION

text: Tools like Tera Term, PuTTY, or RealTerm help visualize sent/received
label: SUBSECTION

text: Clearly document UART configurations (baud rate, parity, stop bits, etc.) in
label: SUBSECTION

text: your code or header files to ensure compatibility in future development.​

text: The universal asynchronous receiver-transmitter (UART) module provides an interface for serial communication
label: PARAGRAPH

text: This interface can be used transfer data between a MSPM0 device and another device with an asynchronous
label: PARAGRAPH

text: serial communication protocol like LIN (local interconnection network), ISO7816 (Smart card protocol), IrDA
label: PARAGRAPH

text: (infrared data association), hardware flow control (CTS/RTS) and multiprocessor communications are supported.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The UART controller includes the following features:
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Even, odd, stick, or no-parity bit generation and detection
label: PARAGRAPH

text: LSB-first or MSB-first data transmit and receive
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Glitch filter on the input signals
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Programmable baud-rate generation with oversampling by 16, 8 or 3
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Separated transmit and receive 4 depth FIFOs reduce CPU interrupt service loading
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Active in all low-power mode including stop and standby mode
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Support for waking up SYSOSC via an asynchronous fast clock request upon start bit detection when
label: PARAGRAPH

text: operating in low power modes (supports up to 19200B rates when using SYSOSC in FCL mode (1%
label: PARAGRAPH

text: section. After enabling the UART module by setting the ENABLE bit,
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the module will be ready to start receiving and transmitting data.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UART communications require two pins: Receive Data (RX) and Transmit Data (TX):
label: PARAGRAPH

text: RX (Receive Data): RX is the serial data input. Glitch filter and oversampling techniques are used on the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: receive signal to ensure accurate incoming data.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: TX (Transmit Data): TX is the serial data output. When the transmitter is enabled and no data needs to be
label: PARAGRAPH

text: transmitted, the TX pin will be held high. In some bidirectional protocols like ISO7816 Smart card, this pin is
label: PARAGRAPH

text: In hardware flow control mode, the following pins are also used:
label: PARAGRAPH

text: CTS (Clear To Send): when driven high by external signal, this signal blocks the data transmission at the end
label: PARAGRAPH

text: RTS (Request To Send): when low, this signal indicates that the UART is ready to receive data.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UART transmits and receives characters at a bit rate that is asynchronous to another device. Timing for each
label: PARAGRAPH

text: character is based on the selected baud-rate. The transmit and receive functions use the same baud-rate
label: PARAGRAPH

text: In general, control registers should only be programmed when the UART is disabled (ENABLE bit in the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UARTx.CTL0 register is cleared). If the UART is operating and gets disabled during transmit or receive
label: PARAGRAPH

text: operation, the current transaction gets completed before the UART stops. The baud-rate divisor registers
label: PARAGRAPH

text: (UARTx.IBRD and UARTx.FBRD) can be modified without disabling the UART.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The transmit logic performs parallel-to-serial conversion on the data read from the transmit FIFO. The control
label: PARAGRAPH

text: logic outputs the serial bit stream beginning with a start bit and followed by the data bits (LSB first), parity bit,
label: PARAGRAPH

text: and the stop bits according to the programmed configuration.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The receive logic performs serial-to-parallel conversion on the received bit stream after a valid start pulse has
label: PARAGRAPH

text: been detected. Overrun, parity, frame error checking, and line-break detection are also performed, and their
label: PARAGRAPH

text: status accompanies the data that is written to the receive FIFO, this is the reason for 12-bit receive FIFO.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UARTx.CTL0.ENABLE bit is used to enable and disable the UART module, UARTx.CTL0.TXE and RXE bits are
label: PARAGRAPH

text: used to enable the transmit and receive mode, UARTx.LCRH.WLEN bit is used to configure the number of data
label: PARAGRAPH

text: bits transmitted or received in a frame, UARTx.LCRH.PEN is used to enable parity and UARTx.LCRH.STP2 is
label: PARAGRAPH

text: used to send two stop bits.
label: TABLE_ROW

text: By default, UARTx.CTL0.HSE is set to 0 and 16 oversampling is selected and receiving bits are expected to
label: PARAGRAPH

text: have the length of 16 UART clock UARTclk cycles and is sampled on the 8th UARTclk cycle.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Setting the UARTx.CTL0.HSE bit to 1 selects the 8 oversampling where the receiving bits are expected to have
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the length of 8 UART clock UARTclk cycles and is sampled on the 4th UARTclk cycle.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Setting the UARTx.CTL0.HSE bit to 2 selects the 3 oversampling, the receiving bits are expected to have the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: length of 3 UART clock UARTclk cycles and are sampled on the 2nd UARTclk cycle.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The aforementioned scenarios assume an IBRD =1 and FBRD =0.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Select oversampling by 3 or 8 to achieve higher speed with UARTclk/8 or UARTclk/3. In this case the receiver
label: PARAGRAPH

text: tolerance to clock deviation is reduced.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Select oversampling by 16 to increase the tolerance of the receiver to clock deviations. The maximum speed
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The majority voting feature of the UART provides noise immunity by sampling each bit 3 times in the center
label: PARAGRAPH

text: of the bit period. For example, in the case when the UARTx.CTL0.HSE is set to 0 with 16 oversampling; the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: 7th, 8th and 9th bit are sampled and the majority value is considered as final value to be sampled. When the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UARTx.CTL0.HSE is set to 1 with 8 oversampling; then the 3rd ,4th and 5th bits are sampled and majority value
label: PARAGRAPH

text: is considered as final value to be sampled. The oversampling is only applicable for 16 and 8 oversampling.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: When the 3 samples used for majority vote are not equal; the RIS.NE (noise error bit) is set. The received data
label: PARAGRAPH

text: is transferred despite the noise error. The NE bit will get appended to the received data before storing it in the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: RXDATA register at bit position 12. Please note that the majority voting feature is implemented only for data bits.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: One can select majority voting or single sample using the MAJVOTE control bit in the CTL0 register.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Even though UART instances have noise filters, this feature provides an extra layer of noise immunity
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The baud-rate divisor is a 22-bit number consisting of a 16-bit integer and a 6-bit fractional part. The number
label: PARAGRAPH

text: formed by these two values is used by the baud-rate generator to determine the bit sample period. Having a
label: PARAGRAPH

text: fractional baud-rate divisor allows the UART to generate all of the standard baud-rates very accurately
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The 16-bit integer is loaded through the UART Integer Baud-Rate Divisor UARTx.IBRD register and the 6-bit
label: PARAGRAPH

text: fractional part is loaded with the UART Fractional Baud-Rate Divisor UARTx.FBRD register.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The baud-rate divisor can be calculated by using the following formula:
label: PARAGRAPH

text: BRD = UART Clock / (Oversampling x Baud rate)
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UART clock is the clock output of the UART clock control logic, configured by CLKSEL and CLKDIV.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Oversampling is selected by the HSE bit in the UARTx.CTL0 register and it can be 16, 8 or 3.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UARTx.IBRD = INT(BRD), integer part of the BRD
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The integer part of BRD is loaded into UARTx.IBRD register. The 6-bit fractional number must be loaded into the
label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

text: 65535 (that is 0xFFFF), then FBRD must not be greater than zero. If this is exceeded it results in an
label: BULLET_POINT

text: When updating the baud-rate divisor (UARTx.IBRD or UARTx.IFRD), the UART.LCRH register must also be
label: PARAGRAPH

text: written, so any changes to the baud-rate divisor must be followed by a write to the LCRH register for the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: changes to take effect. The contents of the UART.IBRD and UART.FBRD registers are not updated until
label: PARAGRAPH

text: transmission or reception of the current character is complete.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Data received or transmitted is stored in two FIFOs, though the receive FIFO has an extra four bits per character
label: PARAGRAPH

text: For transmission, data is written into the transmit FIFO. If the UART is enabled, it causes a data frame to start
label: PARAGRAPH

text: transmitting with the parameters indicated in the UARTx.LCRH register. Data continues to be transmitted until
label: PARAGRAPH

text: there is no data left in the transmit FIFO. The BUSY bit in the UARTx.STAT register is asserted as soon as
label: PARAGRAPH

text: data is written to the transmit FIFO (that is, if the FIFO is nonempty) and remains asserted while data is being
label: PARAGRAPH

text: transmitted. The BUSY bit is negated only when the transmit FIFO is empty, and the last character has been
label: PARAGRAPH

text: transmitted to the shift register, including the stop bits. The UART can indicate that it is busy even though the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UART can no longer be enabled. BUSY also is set during the generation of a BREAK signal.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: When the receiver is idle (the RX signal is continuously 1), and the data input goes low (a start bit has
label: PARAGRAPH

text: been received), the receive counter begins running and data is sampled on the different cycle based on the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: oversampling setting of the HSE bit in UARTx.CTL0 register .The start bit is valid and recognized if the RX
label: PARAGRAPH

text: signal is still low after certain number for cycles based on the oversampling setting. After a valid start bit is
label: PARAGRAPH

text: detected, successive data bits are sampled according to the programmed length of the data characters. The
label: PARAGRAPH

text: parity bit is then checked if parity mode is enabled. Data length and parity are defined in the UART.LCRH
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Lastly, a valid stop bit is confirmed if the RXD signal is high, otherwise a framing error has occurred. When a full
label: PARAGRAPH

text: word is received, the data is stored in the receive FIFO along with any error bits associated with that word.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: For received data, the data byte and the 4-bit status (break, frame, parity, and overrun) is pushed onto the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: 12-bit wide receive FIFO. The error and status can be can be retrieved by reading UARTx.RXDATA register as
label: BULLET_POINT

text: A framing error occurs when a low stop bit is detected. When two stop bits are used, both
label: PARAGRAPH

text: stop bits are checked for framing error. When a framing error is detected, the FRMERR bit
label: PARAGRAPH

text: A parity error is a mismatch between the number of 1s in a character and the value of
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the parity bit. When an address bit is included in the character, it is included in the parity
label: PARAGRAPH

text: calculation. When a parity error is detected, the PARERR bit is set.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: An overrun error occurs when a character is loaded into RXDATA/FIFO before the prior
label: PARAGRAPH

text: character has been read. When an overrun occurs, the OVRERR bit is set.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: A break is detected when all received data, parity, and stop bits are 0. When a break
label: PARAGRAPH

text: condition is detected, the BRKERR bit is set. A break condition can also set the interrupt
label: PARAGRAPH

text: flag RXINT if the break interrupt enable IMASK.BRKERR bit is set.
label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

text: Flow control can be accomplished by hardware and the following sections describe the implementation method.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: In UART mode (CTL0.MODE set to 0), hardware flow control between two devices is accomplished by
label: PARAGRAPH

text: connecting the RTS output to the CTS input on the receiving device, and connecting the RTS output on the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: receiving device to the CTS input. The RTS output signal is low active, the CTS input expects a low signal on a
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The CTS input controls the transmitter, the Device 0 and Device 1 transmitter can only transmit data when
label: PARAGRAPH

text: their CTS input is asserted low. When RTS flow control is enabled, the RTS output signal indicates the state
label: PARAGRAPH

text: of the receive FIFO. For example, the CTS of the Device 1 remains asserted low until the preprogrammed RX
label: PARAGRAPH

text: FIFO level of Device 0 is reached, indicating that the receive FIFO of Device 0 has no space to store additional
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The CTSEN and RTSEN bits in the UART.CTL0 register specify the flow control mode as shown in
label: PARAGRAPH

text: RTS and CTS flow control enabled
label: PARAGRAPH

text: Both RTS and CTS flow control disabled
label: PARAGRAPH

text: When RTSEN is set to 1, the value of the CTL0.RTS bit is ignored and the RTS output signal is generated by the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: hardware trigger levels as described below. When RTSEN bit is cleared, the RTS signal output is controlled by
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the CTL0.RTS bit for SW control.

text: The RTS flow control logic is linked to the programmable receive FIFO watermark levels, it can be configured
label: PARAGRAPH

text: using UARTx.IFLS register. When RTS flow control is enabled, the RTS is asserted (low) until the receive
label: PARAGRAPH

text: FIFO is filled up to the watermark level. When the receive FIFO watermark level is reached, the RTS signal is
label: PARAGRAPH

text: de-asserted (high), indicating that there is no more room to receive any more data. The transmission of data is
label: PARAGRAPH

text: expected to cease after the current character has been transmitted. The RTS signal is reasserted (low) when
label: PARAGRAPH

text: data has been read out of the receive FIFO so that it is filled to less than the watermark level. If RTS flow control
label: PARAGRAPH

text: If CTS flow control is enabled, then the transmitter checks the CTS signal before transmitting the next byte. If
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the CTS signal is asserted (low), it transmits the byte otherwise transmission does not occur. The data continues
label: PARAGRAPH

text: to be transmitted while CTS is asserted (low), and the transmit FIFO is not empty. If the transmit FIFO is empty
label: PARAGRAPH

text: and the CTS signal is asserted (low) no data is transmitted. If the CTS signal is de-asserted (high) and CTS flow
label: PARAGRAPH

text: control is enabled, then the current character transmission is completed before stopping. If CTS flow control is
label: PARAGRAPH

text: disabled and the UART is enabled, then the data continues to be transmitted until the transmit FIFO is empty.

text: In 9-bit mode, the 9th bit can be controlled by software. The EPS bit setting of the LCRH register reflects the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: If a parity error is detected during a transmission, RXD is pulled low during the second stop bit. In this case,
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the UART aborts the transmission, it flushes the transmit FIFO and discards any data it contains. Additionally
label: PARAGRAPH

text: it raises a parity error interrupt, allowing the software to detect the problem and initiate retransmission of
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the affected data, as the UART does not support automatic retransmission in this case. The UART does not
label: PARAGRAPH

text: support automatic retransmission on parity errors. If a parity error is detected on transmission, all further transmit
label: PARAGRAPH

text: operations are aborted and software must handle retransmission of the affected byte or message.
label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

text: Out of reset, both FIFOs are disabled and act as 1-byte-deep holding registers. The FIFOs are enabled by
label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

text: Hardware monitors empty, full and overrun conditions
label: PARAGRAPH

text: The UARTx.STAT register contains empty and full flags (TXFE, TXFF, RXFE, and RXFF bits), and the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: CPU_INT.RIS register shows overrun status of the receive FIFO through the OVRERR bit. There is no indicator
label: PARAGRAPH

text: for a transmit FIFO overrun. A write is just lost, in case it overruns the transmit FIFO. If the FIFOs are disabled,
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the empty and full flags are set according to the status of the 1-byte-deep holding registers. When receiving
label: PARAGRAPH

text: more data than the FIFO can capture the oldest data will be overwritten with the received data.

text: Digital filter is based on the UART functional clock. The DGFSEL bits in the UARTx.GFCTL register can
label: PARAGRAPH

text: be programmed to provide glitch suppression on the RX line and assure proper signal values. The glitch
label: PARAGRAPH

text: suppression value is in terms of functional clocks. All signals are delayed internally when glitch suppression is
label: PARAGRAPH

text: nonzero. For example, if DGFSEL is set to 0x5, 5 clocks should be added onto the calculation for the expected
label: PARAGRAPH

text: transaction time. The DGFSEL need to be configured for the glitch suppression pulse width to be shorter than
label: PARAGRAPH

text: 1/3 of a normal data pulse, to avoid a normal pulse is filtered unexpectedly.
label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

text: The IFLS register is the interrupt FIFO level select register. You can use this register to define the levels at which

text: the TX, RX and timeout interrupt flags are triggered. The interrupts are generated based on a transition through

label: PARAGRAPH

text: through the trigger level. For example, if the receive trigger level is set to the half-way mark, the interrupt is

label: PARAGRAPH

text: bits are configured so that the FIFOs trigger an interrupt at the half-way mark.

text: UART Transmit Data Register. This register is the transmit data register (the interface to the FIFOs). For
label: PARAGRAPH

text: transmitted data, if the FIFO is enabled, data written to this location is pushed onto the transmit FIFO. If the FIFO
label: PARAGRAPH

text: is disabled, data is stored in the transmitter holding register (the bottom word of the transmit FIFO). A write to
label: PARAGRAPH

text: this register initiates a transmission from the UART.
label: TABLE_ROW

text: Data Transmitted or Received Data that is to be transmitted via the
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UART is written to this field. When read, this field contains the data
label: PARAGRAPH

text: that was received by the UART.
label: PARAGRAPH

text: UART Receive Data Register. This register is the data receive register (the interface to the FIFOs). For received
label: PARAGRAPH

text: data, if the FIFO is enabled, the data byte and the 4-bit status (break, frame, parity, and overrun) is pushed onto
label: PARAGRAPH

text: the 12-bit wide receive FIFO. If the FIFO is disabled, the data byte and status are stored in the receiving holding
label: PARAGRAPH

text: register (the bottom word of the receive FIFO). The received data can be retrieved by reading this register.
label: PARAGRAPH

label: PARAGRAPH

text: flag is cleared by writing 1 to the OVRERR bit in the UART EVENT
label: PARAGRAPH

text: ICLR register. In case of a receive FIFO overflow, the FIFO contents
